item.title: Trump Expected to Announce Kevin Warsh as Fed Chair
item.description: President Trump is set to announce his choice to replace Jerome H. Powell as chair of the Federal Reserve, saying it is someone “known to everybody in the financial world.”
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Ann Saphir/Reuters
item.media:description: President Trump is planning to announce Kevin M. Warsh, a former Federal Reserve governor, as his choice to replace Jerome H. Powell.

item.title: Did Trump Really Give Nicki Minaj a $1 Million ‘Gold Card’ Visa?
item.description: “Gold Trump card free of charge,” the rapper wrote on social media. But the White House says it’s not what it seems.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: The rapper Nicki Minaj greeting President Trump during an event in Washington on Wednesday. She is originally from Trinidad and Tobago and grew up in Queens.

item.title: Trump Weighs New Military Options Against Iran
item.description: The plans being weighed by the president go beyond those he considered weeks ago amid widespread protests against Iran’s government.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt, David E. Sanger and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: The options go beyond the proposals that Mr. Trump was considering two weeks ago as a means of following through on his promise to stop the killing of protesters by Iranian government security forces and affiliated militias.

item.title: War Threats and Ambiguous Evidence: Trump Again Confronts Iran
item.description: There is little sign that Iran has made significant progress in reconstituting its nuclear program, leaving questions about the timing and motive behind potential plans for further attacks.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti, Julian E. Barnes, David E. Sanger and Ronen Bergman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Little has happened in the past six months to indicate that Iran has made significant strides toward rebuilding its capacity to enrich nuclear fuel and fashion a nuclear warhead.

item.title: Maps: Where the U.S. Is Building Up Military Force Near Iran
item.description: President Trump has not authorized military action in Iran, but the U.S. has built up its presence in the region in recent days.
item.dc:creator: Christoph Koettl, Eric Schmitt, Ashley Cai and Daniel Wood
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Democrats Reach Spending Deal With Trump, Seeking to Rein In ICE
item.description: Democrats and the White House agreed to fund the Department of Homeland Security for two weeks while they negotiate restrictions on an immigration crackdown. Senators said they hoped to vote on the deal on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson and Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the Democratic leader, began negotiations with President Trump late Wednesday to try to head off a government shutdown.

item.title: Patrick Schiltz, an Ethicist, Is the Minnesota Judge Blasting ICE
item.description: Judge Patrick Schiltz, an appointee of George W. Bush, became an unlikely critic of the Trump administration’s tactics in Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.media:credit: U.S. District Court for the District of Minnesota
item.media:description: Chief Judge Patrick J. Schiltz has shown increasing frustration and anger with the Trump administration and its tactics in court.

item.title: What Domestic Terrorism Means, and Doesn’t
item.description: The Trump administration has called the Minneapolis shooting victims “domestic terrorists.” Our criminal justice reporter Jonah E. Bromwich explains what that term actually means.
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich, Gilad Thaler, Sutton Raphael and Thomas Vollkommer

item.title: Collins Took Credit for ICE Leaving Maine. Her Democratic Opponents Pounced.
item.description: Political maneuvering by the Democrats hoping to unseat Senator Susan Collins shifted into high gear with the news that ICE had ended its surge there.
item.dc:creator: Jenna Russell
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators gathered in Lewiston, Maine, on Saturday to protest Immigration and Customs Enforcement’s presence in the state.

item.title: Xi’s Military Purge May Set Back His Taiwan Ambitions
item.description: By ousting his top generals, Xi Jinping has secured absolute control, but has also hollowed out the command structure preparing for possible war over Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: Ng Han Guan/Associated Press
item.media:description: Gen. Zhang Youxia was China’s top general until he was placed under investigation in a stunning escalation of Xi Jinping’s purge of the military elite.

item.title: Panama Court Strikes Down Hong Kong Firm’s Canal Contract
item.description: President Trump has said he wants American control of the canal, putting the longtime ports operator, CK Hutchison, in the cross-hairs of the U.S.-China trade conflict.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Nathalia Angarita for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has frequently said he wants the United States to retake control of the Panama Canal.

item.title: Trump and First Lady Attend Premiere of ‘Melania’ at Kennedy Center
item.description: Amazon paid Melania Trump’s production company $40 million for the movie and then paid another $35 million to promote it.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and the first lady arrived for the premiere of the film “Melania” at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: Melania Trump Documentary Premiere: Who Was at the Kennedy Center
item.description: Top White House officials streamed into the Kennedy Center on Thursday for a screening of Amazon’s new documentary about the first lady, Melania Trump.
item.dc:creator: The Styles Desk
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and the first lady, Melania Trump, arriving at the Kennedy Center on Thursday for the premiere of “Melania,” Amazon’s new documentary about Mrs. Trump.

item.title: Venezuelan Lawmakers Approve Sweeping Overhaul of Oil Sector
item.description: Bowing to Trump administration pressure, the new legislation improves conditions for foreign oil companies and opens the way to slash the taxes they pay.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A statue of a hand holding a drilling rig near Venezuela’s state oil company last year.

item.title: U.S. Trade Deficit Widens Despite Trump’s Tariffs
item.description: The monthly trade deficit and imports rebounded in November after shrinking significantly in prior months, new data show.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Trump’s Trade Policies Sort Manufacturers Into Winners and Losers
item.description: Tariffs have protected some companies, but more often they’ve hit the parts and materials many factories need to make finished goods.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Sylvia Jarrus for The New York Times

item.title: Canada Signs Auto Deal With South Korea, Moving Further from the U.S.
item.description: The agreement, while scarce on details, is the latest step by Prime Minister Mark Carney to reduce Canada’s reliance on trade with the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Kim Hong-Ji/Reuters
item.media:description: Cars made by Kia Motors ready to be exported at the company’s shipping yard last year in Pyeongtaek, South Korea.

item.title: Washington Post Plans Cuts to Reshape Newsroom
item.description: The changes are expected to include significant layoffs in areas like sports and international coverage.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wemple, Katie Robertson and Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Justin T. Gellerson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Washington Post’s newsroom in 2017.

item.title: Murdoch and News Corp Take on the West Coast with The California Post
item.description: The expansion of the Murdoch tabloid from its New York roots to the West Coast is the latest sign of the outlet’s national ambitions.
item.dc:creator: Katie Robertson
item.media:credit: Photo-illustration by The New York Times; Photos: Getty Images

item.title: Trump Says Putin Agreed to a Weeklong Pause in Attacks Amid Extreme Cold
item.description: Russia has left thousands of apartment buildings in Kyiv without heat in recent weeks, in a campaign that has appeared aimed at breaking Ukraine’s morale.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Andrew E. Kramer and Paul Sonne
item.media:credit: Sergei Gapon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A building in Kyiv protected by sandbags on Thursday.

item.title: Moscow Airport Sells for Half Off, a Sign of Russia’s Global Isolation
item.description: The government opened the sale to cut-rate bidding for Domodedovo Airport after it received no offers at its initial asking price of $1.7 billion.
item.dc:creator: Nataliya Vasilyeva
item.media:credit: Maxim Shemetov/Reuters
item.media:description: Domodedovo Airport outside Moscow, in 2023.

item.title: Pizza Cutter and a Fork: A Bizarre Bid to Break Mangione Out of Jail
item.description: Federal prosecutors said a man was arrested after he impersonated an F.B.I. agent during a visit to the federal jail in Brooklyn where Luigi Mangione is being held.
item.dc:creator: Hurubie Meko, Santul Nerkar and Jonah E. Bromwich
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times

item.title: How the A.I. Boom Could Push Up the Price of Your Next PC
item.description: A.I. companies are buying up memory chips, causing the prices of those components — which are also used in laptops and smartphones — to soar.
item.dc:creator: Don Clark and Loren Elliott

item.title: California Jury Convicts Ex-Google Engineer of Stealing AI Secrets
item.description: A federal jury found that Linwei Ding stole thousands of confidential files to help him start a company in Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Kelsey McClellan for The New York Times
item.media:description: The case is one of several that have surfaced in recent years against Chinese nationals in the United States as the fight for technological dominance ramps up.

item.title: One Solution for Too Many A’s? Harvard Considers Giving A+ Grades.
item.description: Harvard University has been trying to cut back how many A grades professors give. Now, 53 percent of grades are A’s, down from 60 percent.
item.dc:creator: Mark Arsenault
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Mass.

item.title: South Korean Stocks, Kospi Index Are Trading at a Record High
item.description: Spurred by government policies and the global A.I. boom, the market’s value has jumped by hundreds of billions of dollars. Individual investors have piled in.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Ahn Young-Joon/Associated Press
item.media:description: Traders at a bank celebrating the returns of the benchmark Kospi index, which has more than doubled in the past year.

item.title: Genes May Control Your Longevity, However Healthily You Live
item.description: A new study suggests that those with long-lived families probably have the best prospects of making it to a very old age.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata

item.title: The End of Nuclear Arms Control
item.description: Once the New START treaty ends, we will have returned to an era without limits, when arsenals can reach unconstrained heights.
item.dc:creator: W.J. Hennigan
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: An-My Lê for The New York Times

item.title: Trump’s Board of Peace Is Anything But
item.description: America has conveniently forgotten that it once took the world to end conflicts.
item.dc:creator: Thant Myint-U
item.category: United Nations Department of Peacekeeping Operations
item.media:credit: FPG/Getty Images
item.media:description: A United Nations chamber in New York City around 1947.

item.title: Jimmy Kimmel Teases ‘Melania’
item.description: The late night host said, “Not since ‘The Terminator’ has there been this much excitement for a movie about a European cyborg.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)

item.title: Michael Beck, 65, Dies; First to Report Symptoms of ‘Havana Syndrome’
item.description: As an employee with the N.S.A., he claimed he was exposed to a direct-energy device that led to a diagnosis of Parkinson’s disease at the age of 45.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:credit: Katherine Frey/The Washington Post, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Michael Beck in 2017. He said he began experiencing debilitating symptoms of Havana Syndrome much earlier than many other federal employees.

item.title: Newsom Files Civil Rights Complaint Against Dr. Oz Over Fraud Video
item.description: Dr. Mehmet Oz, a top federal health official, posted a video that accuses Armenian Americans in California of health care fraud.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler
item.category: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
item.media:credit: Alex Wong/Getty Images
item.media:description: Dr. Mehmet Oz, administrator for the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, speaking at the White House earlier this month.

item.title: Winter Storm Forecast to Bring Deep Snow to the Carolinas and Virginia
item.description: Up to a foot is possible this weekend in parts of the Southeast and on Cape Cod, with smaller amounts expected for much of the East Coast.
item.dc:creator: Nazaneen Ghaffar and Erin McCann
item.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
